items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert remains in force as overtopping waves and spray are possible on Wednesday morning (06/10/2021) between 4.15am and 7.45am as a result of unsettled conditions around high tide and strong winds. Areas most at risk are around Spurn Road, whilst Kilnsea Caravan Park and Southfield Farm are at risk between 4.45am and 7am. Strong winds may also generate windblown spray affecting low lying land near the coast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Variable conditions are expected over the coming days, and this flood alert may be updated, approaching spring tides on Friday. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Porlock Weir with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds.  Forecast high water is 19:00 on 05/10/21 with a level of 6.07 mAOD and a Force 7 north westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Coastal conditions should ease with wind speeds dropping for the 06/10/21 high tide at 06:30.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert remains in force as overtopping waves and spray are expected on Wednesday morning (06/10/2021) between 4.15am and 7.15am as a result of unsettled conditions around high tide and strong winds. The areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Kilnsea Village, however strong winds may generate wave and windblown spray affecting exposed coastal areas and roads between these times. Please be careful along exposed footpaths and roads as wind generated waves and overtopping spray could be dangerous. Variable conditions are expected over the coming days, approaching spring tides peaking on Friday, and this alert may be updated. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected to continue throughout Tuesday.
River levels in the River Culm have receded today after the recent heavy rainfall, however river levels will remain high in the River Clyst throughout the day. Flooding of low lying land in the floodplain and roads close to rivers is expected to continue, primarily along the lower reaches of the River Clyst, although we do not expect to meet flood warning levels. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Wednesday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. This Flood Alert is likely to remain in place for several days. A Flood Warning is also in place for Keswick Campsite. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the Upper Wey as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later today 05/10/21.
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow (06/10/21) and then start dropping.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the Cranleigh Waters as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow (06/10/21) and then start dropping.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham. No flooding of properties is expected at this time and no further significant rainfall is forecast, however, roads and low lying land near the River Mole and its tributaries may remain flooded for the next 24 hours. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and checking our defences and structures.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on the 06/10/21.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
River levels are high but steady as a result of heavy rainfall from Tuesday morning. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue until 1 am tomorrow, 06/10/21 around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst. Wednesday is expected to be largely dry. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk until Wednesday morning. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the Medway and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers near Ashurst and Balls Green, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high, but now slowly falling, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and be close to properties near Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. The A281 at Mock Bridge, is likely to be affected by flood water overnight Tuesday (05/10/2021). Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river should continue to fall Tuesday evening, returning to near normal Wednesday evening (06/10/2021). Some roads, including those mentioned in this message, may be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
River levels remain high on the upper River Mole but are now beginning to fall, however, flooding of roads and farmland near watercourses is still possible for the next 24 hours. The river level on the Mole at Horley peaked at lunchtime today. 

We expect river levels to remain high for the next 24 hours but no further significant rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and clearing trash screens.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on the 06/10/2021

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels are high on Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to several days of heavy rain.  Rain is expected throughout daylight hours on Tuesday 05/10/2021. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Overnight on Monday into Tuesday we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Roding catchment. This has meant that levels in the Roding have been rising steadily.
The main areas of concern are Abridge, Loughton and Buckhurst Hill.  Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river tonight on Tuesday 5 October. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 
We expect the river to remain high overnight and may see levels continue to rise in response to the rainfall we have already received.  No further rain is forecast over the next few days.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are continuing to monitor river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages.
This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are high and steady at the Churchover river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rain today, Tuesday 5 October 2021. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Further showers are forecast for later today and then the next few days will be dry. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow monring, Wednesday 6 October 2021 or if the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Mancetter river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey.   
River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Whilst most river levels have fallen in the catchment, the level at the Sherborne Lake river gauge continues to remain above Flood Alert level. As a result the Alert remains and there may be localised flooding to fields and footpaths downstream of Sherborne Lake, so please take care. 
We continue to monitor the improving situation. We are expecting fairly dry weather once this afternoon's showers have passed by. 
This message will be updated by 11:00 on 06/10/21.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the Blackwater have risen, as a result of heavy rainfall, but have plateaued. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for the rest of the day.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Puxton river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected until tomorrow morning, 06/10/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Caunsall to Stourport. Other locations that may be affected include Wolverley and Cookley, Blakedown and Kidderminster.   
Further showers are forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to continue rising until the predicted peak this evening, 05/10/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been clearing weed screens. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 06/10/21 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high and rising through Fittleworth, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and properties near Fittleworth Mill, Fittleworth. River levels in Fittleworth are likely to continue to slowly rise until 10:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021, peaking at a similar height as seen on Monday 04/10/2021. River levels at Lodsbridge near Selham are high, and causing minor flood impacts, but are not predicted to rise significantly higher either, and should begin to slowly fall Tuesday night. River levels between Iping and Midhurst are already falling. In Liss the river has already returned to normal. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. River levels all along the Western Rother should be closer to normal by the weekend. Please keep flood protection measures in place in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are high but steady as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected until 11:00 pm today, 05/10/21 along the River Bourne at Hadlow and Little Mill. Wednesday is expected to be largely dry. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk until 06:00 on 06/10/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Bourne and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cripsey Brook in Epping Forest District Council
items.message:
Overnight on Monday into Tuesday we have seen heavy rainfall in the Cripsey Brook catchment. This has meant that levels in the river have risen.
The main areas of concern are Thornwood Common, North Weald Bassett, Moreton and Chipping Ongar.  Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river tonight on Tuesday 5 October. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 
River levels have now peaked and are slowly dropping, however we expect the river to remain high overnight.  No further rain is forecast over the next few days.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are continuing to monitor river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages.
This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high but starting to fall at the Hints river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rain today, Tuesday 5 October 2021. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook. Further showers are forecast for later today and then the next few days will be dry. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 6 October 2021 or if the situation changes.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. Overnight, almost 25mm of rain was recorded at Wroxall. Most of the rain fell in 3 hours, which is a large amount in a short period of time. From 11:00 this morning (05/10/21) the water level will become noticeably high at Alverstone, rising near to the top of the river bank. Some field flooding may occur at Langbridge. We do not expect access issues at Horringford. Property flooding is not expected. Later this evening (around 21:00) it is possible that minor impact flooding will occur at Golf Links Road. Over the next 5 days, the weather will be fairly settled and dry. At Alverstone, the river should peak around 13:00 this afternoon. At Sandown, it wonâ€™t peak until 23:00. Throughout the course of tomorrow (06/10/21), the river will return to normal. We will continue to monitor the forecast, and will attempt to remove any reported blockages. Pumps used to protect gardens from flooding may be required to operate for a short period of time today. This flood alert will be removed by 11:00 on 06/10/21.

This message has been issued because there is a continued risk that some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from now until tomorrow morning, Wednesday 6th October. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for light showers throughout this evening. Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 6th October.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are high but steady as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue until 1:00 am tomorrow, 06/10/21 around Water Lane and Haxted Road. Wednesday is expected to be largely dry. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk until late morning on 06/10/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Eden and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers around Water Lane and Haxted Road, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse at Barcombe is still high, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect the Anchor Inn at Barcombe Mills. Flood water will also be in fields, gardens and on rural roads along the upper Ouse, including Barcombe Mills road, Fletching Mill Bridge and at Sharpsbridge. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. At Barcombe, river levels should begin to fall by 23:00 Tuesday 05/10/2021, but will remain higher than normal until approximately Wednesday evening. River levels near Ardingly, Lindfield and on Sloop Lane are already falling, and are likely to be near normal by Wednesday morning 06/10/2021. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

River levels have risen on the Rivers Esk and Irthing due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Esk and Irthing, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Rivers Esk and Irthing and other watercourses, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton.
We are clearing debris from screens in the area and will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds.  Forecast high water is 19:00 on 05/10/21 with a level of 6.07 mAOD and a Force 7 north westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect coastal areas at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Coastal conditions should ease with wind speeds dropping for the 06/10/21 high tide at 06:30.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The River Arun is still high and slowly rising between Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pallingham, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. Flood water will continue to affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay. Minor flooding could affect the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst Tuesday evening. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. At Pallingham Quay, river levels should begin to fall by 10:00  06/10/2021, but river levels might not return to normal until Friday. River levels through Horsham and Broadbridge Heath are already slowly falling and are likely to be near normal by Wednesday afternoon. Please keep flood protection products installed, if you have them, until river levels have fallen significantly further. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 11:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

River levels are high on the Rivers Kent, Mint and Bela.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
Further rainfall is forecast until 09:00 PM on Tuesday. We will continue to monitor levels closely but we do not expect any flooding to properties.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont due to persistent heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Lowther and Eamont, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby.
Further rainfall is forecast until 21:00 on Tuesday. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Upper River Eden due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and other watercourses, from Kirkby Stephen to Temple Sowerby including low lying areas around Brough, Warcop, Great Ormside and Appleby.
Further rainfall is forecast until 09:00 PM on Tuesday. We will continue to monitor levels closely but we do not expect any flooding to properties.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The River Arun is high and rising. In the first 5 days of October, we have already measured as much rain as normally expected over the whole month. From 19:00 Wednesday (06/10/2021) flooding could affect the A29 at Pulborough. Water will be extensive through fields and could affect gardens and approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. For four hours after the high tide Wednesday (12:00 midday, 06/10/2021) water could be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. Flooding is not currently expected this week in Arundel or Ford. No rain is forecast until Friday, which should allow the river to peak Thursday evening. The river is unlikely to return to a lower level until next week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 19:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

River levels are rising at the Willington and Shardlow river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from Wednesday morning 06/10/2021.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Greta, St Johns Beck, Glendermackin

items.message:
River levels are high on the Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Derwent from Keswick to Bassenthwaite. The Rivers Greta, Glenderamackin and St Johns Beck including Keswick.
Further rainfall is forecast until 08:00PM on Tuesday. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at 09:00 on 06/10/21 and following high tides. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Rivers Caldew and Petteril due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads near the Rivers Caldew and Petteril from the Lakeland Fells to their confluences with the Eden in Carlisle including Greystoke, Newton Reigny, Plumpton, Stockdalewath, Sebergham and Denton Holme in Carlisle.
No further rainfall is forecast overnight and we do not expect any flooding to properties.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

On Monday and Tuesday we saw heavy rainfall across the area. This caused the river Roding to rise.
The main area of concern is currently Molehill Green, Dunmow, Ongar, Fyfield, High Ongar and Stapleford where the River Roding has risen. There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river this evening on Tuesday 5 October.  Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
We expect the river to continue to rise overnight and then remain high into Wednesday. No further rainfall is expected over the next few days.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Lower River Eden.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.
No further significant rainfall is forecast overnight on Tuesday 05/10/21. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Alwinton and Rothbury river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 20:00 today. River levels are expected to peak during the early hours of Wednesday morning. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday morning (06/10/21).
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have checked defences and cleared screens, and are ready to respond if needed. We are closing Rothbury flood gates over the next few hours and they will remain closed overnight.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued because we expect large waves and spray to affect sea front and coastal areas as a result of rising tides and strong winds. Overtopping waves are expected between 04:00 and 07:00 BST on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021. Areas most at risk are properties in Sandsend and low lying land and roads in sea front locations around the tidal River Esk around the high tide at approximately 04:00-04:15 BST. Tides are continuing to rise towards springs on Friday, 08/10/2021 and we will update this message for successive tides if required. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This flood alert has been issued because we expect large waves and spray to affect sea front and coastal areas as a result of rising tides and strong winds. Overtopping waves are expected between 04:00 and 07:00 BST on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Hornsea Promenade and Leisure Centre. Tides are continuing to rise towards springs on Friday, 08/10/2021 and we will update this message for successive tides if required. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds at Beadnell Harbour Road North and along the Northumberland Coast. Tides will be at their highest at 03:45, on 06/10/21, where flooding may be possible. Flooding and coastal conditions may also occur in the hours either side of high tide between 03:00 on 06/10/21 and 05:15 on 06/10/21. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. We do not expect to close the Warkworth flood gates.
Coastal conditions are expected to continue after high tide until 05:15 on 06/10/21 at Beadnell Harbour Road North and the Northumberland Coast. We are closely monitoring the situation and are ready to respond if needed.    
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 06/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This flood alert has been issued as river levels are rising as a result of todayâ€™s heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this evening and overnight into Wednesday 06/10/2021. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, particularly those around Maunby. Further light rainfall is forecast overnight and we expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow morning. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated before 9am on Wednesday 6th October, or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwentwater is high following several days of rain.  Areas most at risk of flooding include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this warning if necessary. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Anker at Mancetter, Witherley and Atherstone
items.message: River levels are high and steady at the Mancetter river gauge as a result of heavy rain today, Tuesday 5 October 2021. Consequently, the risk of flooding of property, roads and farmland remains. Levels are forecast to start to fall overnight. Further showers are forecast for later today and then the next few days will be dry. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid contact with flood water and call 999 if in immediate danger. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 6 October 2021 or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta
items.message:
River levels are high on the River Greta due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying roads, properties and campsites in Keswick adjacent to the Rivers Greta and Derwent, including Greta Park Rugby Football Ground, Keswick Campsite, Keswick School Sports Field, Keswick Show Field and Playing Field areas.
No further significant rainfall is forecast today 05/10/2021.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning has been issued because we expect large waves and spray to affect sea front and coastal areas as a result of rising tides and strong winds. Overtopping waves are expected between 04:30 and 06:00 BST on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021. Areas most at risk are properties from Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Tides are continuing to rise towards springs on Friday, 08/10/2021 and we will update this message for successive tides if required. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please put your flood plan into action and be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 06/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Esk from Briggswath to Ruswarp
items.message: This flood warning has been issued due to heavy rainfall throughout Tuesday. River levels on the Esk are rising and are expecting to reach 2.1m at Briggswath at 02:15 Wednesday morning, 06/10/21. Levels at Briggswath are forecast to peak between 2.4m and 2.7m at around 03:30, before falling through daylight hours on Wednesday. The main risk is from river flooding but a coastal alert is also in place due to high winds. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, or as the situation changes.
